metadata.title: In-vivo and in-vitro tests to assess toxic mechanisms of nano ZnO to earthworms

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Science of the Total Environment
j ourna l homepage: www.e lsev ie r .com/ locate /sc i totenv
In-vivo and in-vitro tests to assess toxic mechanisms of nano ZnO to earthworms
Ming Li a,b, Yang Yang c, Jiawei Xie d, Guanghui Xu a,b, Yong Yu a,⁎ a Key Laboratory of Wetland Ecology and Environment, Northeast Institute of Geography and Agroecology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Changchun 130102, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c Department of Architectural Engineering, East University of Heilongjiang, Harbin 150066, China d School of Food and Environmental Engineering, East University of Heilongjiang, Harbin 150066, China
H I G H L I G H T S G R A P H I C A L A B S T R A C T
• Zinc entered into earthworms as particulate rather than Zn2 . • Zn2 concentration in earthworms was measured to determine the bioaccumulation. • Biomarkers were applied to assess the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms. • In-vitro toxicity test further determined the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO.
⁎ Corresponding author. E-mail address: yuyong@iga.ac.cn (Y. Yu).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.05.476 0048-9697/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 15 April 2019 Received in revised form 26 May 2019 Accepted 31 May 2019 Available online 01 June 2019
Editor: Jay Gan
Increasing applications of engineered nanomaterials lead to the release of nanoparticles into various environmentalmedia, especially soil. However, the environmental behavior of nano ZnO in soil and the toxicmechanism to terrestrial invertebrates were not fully understood. In this study, the concentrations of nano ZnO in earthworms (Eisenia fetida) were measured to assess its bioaccumulation. The ratio of nano ZnO in earthworms to soil in 250 mg/kg treatment group was lower than that in 10 mg/kg treatment group as the earthworms would not take up too much nano ZnO to protect themselves from the damage. Combination of in-vivo and invitro tests was adapted to investigate the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms. In in-vivo test, biomarkers including ROS, SOD, and MDA suggested that the toxic effects of nano ZnO to earthworms were caused by the oxidative stress. To further elucidate its toxic mechanism, in-vitro toxicity test was carried out by employing earthworm coelomocytes. The biomarkers, intracellular ROS, extracellular LDH, and cell viability showed concentration-dependent manner with nano ZnO in the culture media, demonstrating that in-vitro toxicity test could be utilized to reveal the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms or other organisms.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Keywords: Nano ZnO Earthworms Biomarkers Toxic mechanisms In-vitro toxicity test

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Due to unique physicochemical properties (Pandimurugan and Thambidurai, 2016), nano ZnO was extensively applied into cosmetics and industrial field with estimated amount between 100 and 1000 tons per year worldwide (Zhang et al., 2016). The abundant usage of nano ZnO undoubtedly increases the possibility of releasing into surrounding environment, and thus causes potential detrimental effects to organisms (Ma et al., 2013; Caballero-Guzman and Nowack, 2016). It is reported that 87.3% of released nano ZnO would enter into soils and landfills (Goswami et al., 2017). Therefore, it is necessary to investigate its environmental behavior and toxicity of nano ZnO on terrestrial organisms.
The toxicity of nano ZnO to aquatic organisms has beenwell studied and the toxicitymay vary largely among different trophic levels (Aruoja et al., 2009; Wu et al., 2019). The reported 96 h 50% lethal concentrations (LC50) for Danio rerio (zebrafish) is 3.97 mg/L (Yu et al., 2011). However, the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to terrestrial invertebrates was not fully understood. Earthworms have a large epidermal surface and naturally live in soil. They acclimatize and ingest different types of soil (Lanno et al., 2004; Silvani et al., 2019), and absorb pollutants as the consequence of direct soil contact (Zaltauskaite and Miskelyte, 2018). Previous studies utilized some biomarkers in in-vivo test to determine the toxicity of nano ZnO to earthworms (Canas et al., 2011; Li et al., 2011; Heggelund et al., 2014; Laycock et al., 2016; RomeroFreire et al., 2017).
In-vivo toxicity experiments usually consume more time and materials, whereas in-vitro toxicity tests provide reproducible results without hurting organisms in large scale, which are usually employed in cytotoxicity experiment (Jiang et al., 2017). Earthworm coelomocytes play a key role in identifying and eliminating xenobiotics, immunological response, and phagocytosis in earthworms (Kwak et al., 2014). Several studies utilized earthworm coelomocytes in in-vivo toxicity experiments to determine the toxicity of pollutants (Kwak et al., 2014; Gautam et al., 2018; Verdú et al., 2018). However, earthworm coelomocytes were seldom employed in in-vitro toxicity test.
Although some studies have been conducted to determine toxicity of nano ZnO, the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms has not been fully understood (Ma et al., 2013). In this study, Eisenia fetida (E. fetida) is applied to determine the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms as it is widely utilized as a model organism in toxicity tests (Shao et al., 2018). A series of biomarkers for in-vivo and in-vitro tests were utilized to investigate the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms. The aims of this study were to systematically elucidate the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms and build up the relationship between the biomarkers and the Zinc concentrations in the earthworms or substrate. The clarification of this relationship will provide insights into the toxic mechanisms of nanoparticles to terrestrial organisms.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Earthworms (E. fetida) were purchased from the Anding company (Suihua, China). Nano ZnO was acquired from Deke Nano technology Co., LTD (Beijing, China). Phosphate buffered saline (PBS) was purchased from Boster Biological Technology Co. Ltd. (Wuhan, China). Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) assay kit, superoxide dismutase (SOD) assay kit, malondialdehyde (MDA) assay kit, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) assay reagent were obtained from Nanjing Jiancheng Bioengineering Institute (Nanjing, China).

sections.heading: 2.2. In-vivo exposure assay
sections.text:
The concentrations of nano ZnO in the soil were selected as 10, 50, 250 mg/kg. The method to culture the earthworms was according to
the guidelines of the OECD (Shao et al., 2018), the details are shown in the Supplementary data. On day 7, 14, 21, and 28, earthworms were sampled to determine the Zn2 concentration and the physiological indexes.
To measure the Zn2 concentrations, earthworms were digested in 14mL of amixture of HNO3 andH2O2 (v/v, 5:2). Digestionwas operated in Teflon bombs, placed in an oven at 140 °C for 6 h. After digestion, the samples were added with 1% HNO3 solution and analyzed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, ICP5000, Focused Photonics Inc.).

sections.heading: 2.3. Dissociation experiment of nano ZnO
sections.text: To determine the dissociation of Zn2 from nano ZnO in soil and the culture media, soil (20 g, moisture 20%) was spiked with nano ZnO at 10, 50 and 250 mg/kg, culture media was spiked with nano ZnO at 10 and 50 μg/mL. On each sampling day (day 1, 7, 14, 21, and 28), the soil (20 g) was added with deionized water (36 mL) and shaken for 30min, then centrifuged for 10min (3500 rpm). The culturemedia containing nano ZnOwas incubated for 24 h, and then directly centrifuged for 15min (4000 rpm). The supernatant was collected to determine the Zn2 concentration by ICP-OES.

sections.heading: 2.4. Measurement of physiological indexes in earthworms
sections.text: ROS content was measured by dichlorofluorescin diacetate (DCFHDA) method (Shao et al., 2018). The details are shown in the Supplementary data. For measuring SOD and MDA contents, the earthworms in each group were cut into pieces and added into 0.85% NaCl (4 °C) solution. The mixture was ultra-sonicated and centrifuged. The supernatant was collected to measure protein, SOD and MDA contents by commercial kits (Nanjing Jiancheng LTD, China). ROS, SOD, and MDA contents were standardized by protein content.

sections.heading: 2.5. In-vitro toxicity test
sections.text: Earthworm coelomocytes utilized in in-vitro toxicity test were extracted according to the former methods (Garcia-Velasco et al., 2017; Patricia et al., 2017), the details are shown in Supplementary data. The body cavity of the earthworm was pierced until the yellow liquid appeared. The yellow liquid was rinsed with the Hanks solution and centrifuged to obtain the coelomocytes. The earthworm coelomocytes (180 μL) were inoculated into 96-well plates and incubated for 24 h at 25 °C. Then cell solution was added into each well and spiked with nano ZnO (0.05–50 μg/mL) and cultured for 24 h. Cell viabilitywasmeasured by the following procedure: 10 μL of Cell Counting Kit-8 (CCK-8) was added into each well. After cultivation for another 4 h, the absorbancewasmeasured by amicroplate reader at 450 nm. Themorphological changes of earthworm coelomocytes exposed to different concentrations of nano ZnO for 24 h were observed by an inverted microscope (Nikon, Ti\\S). Intracellular ROS were analyzed by the DCFHDA method. The cells were incubated with DCFH-DA at 37 °C in the dark for 30 min, and then washed twice with cold PBS. The precipitant was collected to determine the ROS content. The cell suspension in 96-well plate was blown evenly and transferred into 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes. The tubes were centrifuged for 15min (4 °C, 4000 rpm), then the supernatant was collected to determine LDH activities by commercial kits.

sections.heading: 3.1. Dissociation of nano ZnO in soil
sections.text:
The nano ZnO was firstly analyzed by transmission electron microscope (TEM). As shown in Fig. S1, the size of nano ZnO ranged from 20 to 30 nm, which ensures that the nano ZnO could enter into the
earthworm body (Hu et al., 2010; Hooper et al., 2011; Li et al., 2011). The dissociation of nanoparticles is affected by several factors, such as size, surface area, surface curvature, and roughness of the particles (Farre et al., 2009), and nano ZnO is nearly insoluble in water (Suman et al., 2015). Before the toxicity experiment, the dissociation of this commercial nano ZnO in soil was measured to determine the existence state during the experiment. As shown in Fig. S2, dissociation capability of the nano ZnO in artificial soil (pH = 6.5) and culture media ranged from 0.06 to 0.68% and from 0.07 to 0.86%, respectively. It suggested that the dissociation of nano ZnO could be neglected and themain existence state of Zinc in the soil and culturemedia was particulate, demonstrating that earthworms would take up nano ZnO rather than the Zn2 (Hooper et al., 2011; Laycock et al., 2016; Romero-Freire et al., 2017).

sections.heading: 3.2. Accumulation of nano ZnO in earthworms
sections.text:
To accurately determine the accumulation of nano ZnO in earthworms, the background Zn2 in earthworms and soil were measured. Zn2 concentration in unexposed soil was 4.4 ± 0.3 μg/g. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Zn2 concentrations in earthworms (dry) of control group (blank) ranged from 24.8 ± 12.3 to 29.3± 9.8 μg/g. Zn2 concentrations in earthworms increased with exposure time and nano ZnO concentrations in soil. Zn2 concentrations in all treatment groups were significantly higher than that in the control group (p b 0.05). The ratio of nano ZnO in earthworms to soil was calculated by deducting the background Zn2 in the unexposed earthworms and soil. As shown in Fig. 1b, the ratios decreased with the nano ZnO concentrations in soil and increased with exposure time. The ratios in lower nano ZnO groups (10, 50 mg/kg) on day 28 were 12.6 and 3.6, respectively. The ratio in the highest group (250 mg/kg) was lower than 1 on day 28, with Zn2 concentration of 179 ± 51.9 μg/g. Oral ingestion of soil and
porewater is themajor routine for uptake of ZnO into earthworms, dermal uptake only accounts for ~5% of the total ZnO accumulation (Laycock et al., 2016). It suggested that the earthworms in the higher nano ZnO concentration groups (50, 250 mg/kg) would not actively take up too much nano ZnO to avoid toxicity, leading to lower ratios compared to those in low nano ZnO concentration and control group.

sections.heading: 3.3. Toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms
sections.text:
Biomarkers are usually employed to determine the toxic mechanisms and reveal the biochemical, physiological, ecological structures or processes linking to biological effects at a sub-organism level of biological organization (Yan et al., 2019). Antioxidant enzyme could protect cells from the toxic effects of ROS and increased antioxidant enzyme in organisms is regarded as an early warning indicator of pollutions in the environment (Song et al., 2009).
The size of nanomaterialsmay promote their uptake and interaction with biological tissues, resulting in harmful biological effects on living cells (Nel et al., 2006). In this study, the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO was determined by measuring a series of biomarkers in earthworms.
Solubilized Zn2 from nano ZnO has been proven to contribute substantially to the cytotoxicity of the Zinc (Brunner et al., 2006; Heinlaan et al., 2008). However, the majority of the nano ZnO in the artificial soil in this study was particulate, therefore, it is assumed that the ingested formof Zinc by earthwormswasnanoZnO rather than Zn2 . Besides the toxicity caused by Zn2 dissociated from the nano ZnO (Suman et al., 2015; Romero-Freire et al., 2017), particle-induced effects stand for another toxic mechanism of nano ZnO (Ma et al., 2013). Nanomaterials-induced toxicity is usually ROS-mediated. ROS originates from the particle surface as a result of thematerial semiconductor or electronic properties of certain materials to disturb electronic shift procedures in the cell (Zhang et al., 2007; Lin and Xing, 2008; Applerot et al., 2009). It is also reported that Zn2 would induce the organisms to produce excess ROS (Applerot et al., 2009). As shown in Fig. 2a, the highest ROS content was found on day 28 in 250 mg/kg nano ZnO treatment group, which was 381 fluorescence intensity per mg protein and 2.4 times of that in control group. The ROS significantly increased with exposure time and nano ZnO in soil or the Zn2 in the earthworms, suggesting that nano ZnO caused oxidative damage to the earthworms. The generation of ROS caused by nano ZnO was also found to induce damage to zebrafish (Bai et al., 2010; Zhao et al., 2013).
When the ROS is over generated, the anti-oxidases such as SOD are stimulated to scavenge free radicals (Yue et al., 2018). As shown in Fig. 2b, the SOD activities in earthworms increased significantly in lower treatment groups (10, 50 mg/kg), which was consistent with the ROS increment (Yan et al., 2019). However, SOD activities decreased from day 14 in the highest nano ZnO treatment group (250 mg/kg). Highly reactive O2 surpassing the anti-oxidant defense capability leads to the failure of antioxidant defense system in earthworms (Shao et al., 2018) and the decline of SOD activities. When the balance between the production and scavenging of ROS is disturbed, the accumulation of excessive ROS would induce the peroxidation of membrane lipids. MDA, the oxidized product of membrane lipids, was usually employed as an indicator of lipid peroxidation (Gao et al., 2019). As shown in Fig. 2c, the MDA contents in control group were quite stable and ranged from 0.1 to 0.2 mmol per mg protein. The MDA content in all treatment groups significantly increased compared to control group with the highest MDA content of 5.1 mmol per mg protein, suggesting that the excessive accumulation of ROS existed in all treatment groups, leading to oxidative stress to earthworms. The ROS, SOD, and MDA contents showed concentration-dependent manner with the Zn2
in the earthworms. However, these biomarkers did not show concentration-dependent manner with nano ZnO in the soil. Therefore, it is necessary to explore a newmethod to build up the relationship between toxicity and nano ZnO in substrate.

sections.heading: 3.4. Biomarker responses in earthworm coelomocytes
sections.text:
In-vitro toxicity tests may greatly reduce the usage of materials and shorten the experimental time. In this study, the earthworm coelomocytes were extracted and innovatively employed in in-vitro toxicity test. The earthworm coelomocytes were directly exposed to
nano ZnO in culture media, therefore, this method may facilitate the toxicity assessment of nano ZnO.
As shown in Fig. 3a, the intracellular ROS content increased with concentrations of nano ZnO in the culture media. The ROS in highest concentration (50 μg/mL) treatment group increased 75.9% compared to that in control (blank) group, indicating that the existence of nano ZnOwould induce the ROS generation (Wu et al., 2019). Nano ZnO surface in culture media could react with H2O and produce hydroxyl radicals (Ma et al., 2013), and thus lead to the accumulation of ROS in earthworm coelomocytes. The increment of ROS in the earthworm coelomocytes would bring harmful effect to cell membrane (Liu et al., 2019) and directly demonstrated that toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms was the ROS mediation.
When the cell membrane is damaged, the intracellular LDHwill leak into the culture media, therefore, extracellular LDH could be utilized to reflect the coelomocytes damage. As shown in Fig. 3b, the extracellular LDH increased with nano ZnO concentrations in the culture media, revealing that the cell membrane was indeed damaged and resulted in the leakage of intracellular LDH. Hydroxyl radicals cause damage to
DNA, lipids, polysaccharides, and proteins (Aliakbari et al., 2019). Therefore, the increment of intracellular ROS will cause potential damage to the cell and the leakage of intracellular substance e.g., LDH (Panieri and Santoro, 2016). As shown in Fig. 3c, the cell viability declined with increasing concentrations of nano ZnO. The cell viability in 50 μg/mL treatment groupwas77.5% anddecreasedby12.3% (p b 0.01) compared to that in control (blank) group, indicating that the nano ZnO caused damage to cell membrane and resulted in the leakage of intracellular substance, eventually led to the death of earthworm coelomocytes. Themorphological changes of earthworm coelomocytes exposed to different concentrations of nano ZnOare shown in Fig. S3, whichwere consistent with the cell viability. All the biomarkers (intracellular ROS, extracellular LDH, and cell viability) showed correlation with the nano ZnO concentrations in culture media, demonstrating that in-vitro toxicity test could be employed to reveal the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: The accumulation of ZnO in earthworms increased with time and nano ZnO in soil. The results of in-vivo toxicity experiment showed that nano ZnO led to excess ROS in earthworms and caused oxidative damage to earthworms. Biomarkers in in-vitro toxicity test including intracellular ROS, extracellular LDH, and cell viability showed concentration-dependent manner with nano ZnO in culture media, demonstrating that in-vitro toxicity test could build up the relationship between toxic effects and pollutants in substrate. The in-vitro test further elucidated the toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms, indicating that nano ZnO caused excessive production of intracellular ROS and resulted in the death of coelomocytes. This study contributed knowledges to bioaccumulation of nanoparticles in soil and their toxicity to terrestrial invertebrates.

sections.text: We are grateful to the grants from the Strategic Priority Research Program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (Grant No. XDA23070502), Research Foundation for Talents of Northeast Institute of Geography and Agroecology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (Y6H1211001) and Jilin Provincial Full-time Creative Talents (Y7D7021001).

sections.text: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2019.05.476.

Due to unique physicochemical properties (Pandimurugan and Thambidurai, 2016), nano ZnO was extensively applied into cosmetics and industrial field with estimated amount between 100 and 1000 tons per year worldwide (Zhang et al., 2016).

The abundant usage of nano ZnO undoubtedly increases the possibility of releasing into surrounding environment, and thus causes potential detrimental effects to organisms (Ma et al., 2013; Caballero-Guzman and Nowack, 2016).

In-vivo toxicity experiments usually consume more time and materials, whereas in-vitro toxicity tests provide reproducible results without hurting organisms in large scale, which are usually employed in cytotoxicity experiment (Jiang et al., 2017).
Earthworm coelomocytes play a key role in identifying and eliminating xenobiotics, immunological response, and phagocytosis in earthworms (Kwak et al., 2014).

Biomarkers are usually employed to determine the toxic mechanisms and reveal the biochemical, physiological, ecological structures or processes linking to biological effects at a sub-organism level of biological organization (Yan et al., 2019).

Antioxidant enzyme could protect cells from the toxic effects of ROS and increased antioxidant enzyme in organisms is regarded as an early warning indicator of pollutions in the environment (Song et al., 2009).

Nano ZnO surface in culture media could react with H2O and produce hydroxyl radicals (Ma et al., 2013), and thus lead to the accumulation of ROS in earthworm coelomocytes.

The increment of ROS in the earthworm coelomocytes would bring harmful effect to cell membrane (Liu et al., 2019) and directly demonstrated that toxic mechanism of nano ZnO to earthworms was the ROS mediation.
